author: Abc Radio Hobart
title: Tasmanian kelp forests dying as water warms, dive operator Mick Baron says - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: Eaglehawk Neck 7179 
There are fears Tasmania's giant kelp forests are almost extinct, as a Senate inquiry into the impact of climate change on sea life begins. 
Once strewn along the south-east coast of Tasmania, the kelp has been completed wiped out off Eaglehawk Neck, dive tour operator Mick Baron told ABC Radio Hobart. 
Mr Baron is among a number of stakeholders giving evidence at a Senate inquiry in Hobart today. 
The Environment and Communications Reference Committee is examining the current and future impacts of climate change on Australia's marine fisheries and biodiversity. 
Mr Baron, who has conducted dive tours off Eaglehawk Neck for 25 years, said climate change was destroying the kelp forests. 
Listed as endangered in 2012 , the kelp is the world's largest marine plant and thrives in cold, nutrient-rich water. 
Mr Baron has documented their decline. 
"When we started the dive centre we had forests everywhere, but 25 years later - nothing," he said. 
"If you come down and dive with us now you do not have any forest remaining - they have all disappeared at the end of summer last year." 
Mr Baron said the last remaining forests in Tasmania were south of Bruny Island, but even those were thinning rapidly. Climate change to blame: Baron 
He blamed climate change. 
"It's not an assessment, it's a fact," he said. 
He said the forests have suffered in the relatively warm, nutrient-poor East Australian Current while not getting a rejuvenating hit from the Southern Ocean during winter. 
Mr Baron believed there was no coming back. 
"In my opinion, they're gone forever", he said. 
"There might be an occasional regeneration on a very small scale but the trend over all those years ... nutrient levels are just too low to maintain decent levels of growth." 
A number of scientists from Tasmania's Institute of Marine and Antarctic Studies will also give evidence to the inquiry.
